image.altText: A woman in glasses sitting in a power wheelchair.

items.synopsis: A disability advocate's call for all Adelaide taxis to be made fully accessible is being considered by the SA government — but it says a solution will not be in next week's state budget.

title.children: Unreliable access taxis 'compromise safety' of people with disabilities, advocate says

image.altText: Business people walk outside the Reserve Bank of Australia.

items.synopsis: Economists are divided on whether interest rates will rise for the 12th time in just over a year, while the Australian share market is trading lower. Follow live.

title.children: Economists split on looming RBA interest rate decision as households and markets brace for possible rise

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Reserve Bank has raised the cash rate to 4.1%, a level not seen since early 2012. The bank's board decided to lift the cash rate target by 0.25 of a percentage point for the second month in a row, amid concerns inflation is taking too long to come down.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: BREAKING: RBA lifts cash rate to 4.1%

children.content: The Reserve Bank has raised the cash rate to 4.1%, a level not seen since early 2012.
The bank's board decided to lift the cash rate target by 0.25 of a percentage point for the second month in a row, amid concerns inflation is taking too long to come down.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We're a little less than 15 minutes away from finding out what the RBA has decided to do with the cash rate this month. I'll bring you the updates as they happen live here on the blog, but you can also watch the decision live with this stream below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Where to watch the RBA's interest rate decision

children.content: from finding out what the RBA has decided to do with the cash rate this month.
I'll bring you the updates as they happen live here on the blog, but you can also watch the decision live with this stream below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Latitude Financial say they have compromised my personal info. I have never been with them. That's a concern. - Natty. Hi Natty — even if you haven't been a Latitude customer directly, you might have applied for a financial product with them years ago, before they were even known as Latitude Financial. Before the Latitude brand became a household name (and a feature on the back of the Richmond Tigers guernsey, if you're AFL inclined like myself), they were GE Money — and have quite the history, including as Coles and Myer-branded credit cards. I did a deep dive on Latitude's history back in April, which you can read below. Hopefully it sheds some light into why you might have been contacted (and sorry to hear you've been caught up in their cyber breach).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: If you've been contacted by Latitude Financial, this might be why

featuredLink.title: Latitude Financial only has 3 million customers, so why did it have 14 million personal records on file?

children.content: Latitude Financial say they have compromised my personal info. I have never been with them. That's a concern.
Hi Natty — even if you haven't been a Latitude customer directly, you might have applied for a financial product with them years ago, before they were even known as Latitude Financial.

image.altText: Chau with his mother-in-law, wife Trang and son Daniel.

items.synopsis: The family of a retired Sydney baker jailed in Vietnam for 12 years on "terrorism" offences express new hope for his freedom after Anthony Albanese's visit to the South-East Asian nation.

title.children: 'She cannot wait to see her husband again': New hopes for Australian detained in Vietnam, after PM's visit

image.altText: Philip Lowe wearing glasses and a suit sits at a table and speaks.

items.synopsis: There is one issue that stands head and shoulders above the rest as Philip Lowe's greatest threat in the battle to control inflation, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: The property market rebound could see us heading into uncharted and dangerous territory

image.altText: A suburban street; a white, one-storey house on the left and an unfinished two-storey house on the right

items.synopsis: The construction industry insolvency crisis is sweeping the nation, and it's devastating for both consumers and builders. So what can be done about it?

title.children: Builders go bust in record numbers, leaving thousands of Australian home owners in the lurch

image.altText: A young man.

items.synopsis: Joel Russo, who was only months out of prison when he repeatedly raped a female jogger on the banks of Melbourne's Merri Creek is jailed for more than 20 years.

title.children: Serial rapist jailed for 'horrendous' attack on female jogger along Melbourne creek

image.altText: A close up of Angus speaking against a dark blue background.

items.synopsis: Shadow Treasurer Angus Taylor says Australia has higher core inflation than all of the countries in the G7. Is that correct? RMIT ABC Fact Check investigates.

title.children: Fact check: Is Australia's core inflation higher than all countries in the G7?

image.altText: Two middle aged women leaning together with big smiles

items.synopsis: Ms Folbigg spent her first day of freedom since 2003 enjoying simple pleasures, like a comfortable bed and pizza, her best friend Tracy Chapman says.

title.children: Kathleen Folbigg 'extremely humbled' and 'grateful' after release

image.altText: a woman lying on the green grass with a baby by her side

items.synopsis: Extensive scientific and medical evidence proved to be key to setting Kathleen Folbigg free, 20 years after she was convicted of killing her four children.

title.children: The one-in-35-million mutation and the science that set Kathleen Folbigg free

image.altText: Image of a CCTV camera in front of street art of Aboriginal girl

items.synopsis: Coober Pedy's council has clarified that the proposed CCTV cameras for the town's CBD will not have facial recognition capabilities after a local business owner raised concerns.

title.children: Council shuts down rumours new CCTV cameras will have facial recognition tech

image.altText: A woman outside a court building in handcuffs.

items.synopsis: Crystal Leanne Hanley is granted home detention bail to clean up her SA Housing rental property, which the prosecutor has described as being "unsuitable for human habitation".

title.children: Woman charged with daughter's manslaughter granted home detention bail to clean up 'squalid' rental

image.altText: A large grassy hill surrounded by trees, with a large patch of burnt grass visible

items.synopsis: Authorities are thinking of expanding a program involving burning for grass seedling regeneration after encouraging results at South Australian reserves using techniques that have been used for thousands of years by traditional owners.

title.children: Regenerative patch burns in grassy woodland areas prove a blooming success

image.altText: Tasmanian petrol prices falling

items.synopsis: A Tasmanian man who used a company fuel card to buy more than $24,000 worth of fuel, some of which he onsold to friends, avoids prison — the court acknowledging his marriage breakdown caused "great upheaval" for him before the offending started.

title.children: Man uses employer's fuel card to unlawfully buy more than $20k of petrol

image.altText: A young woman standing at a cash register looks at a woman sorting her groceries in a trolley.

items.synopsis: The odds have been shortening on the Reserve Bank of Australia lifting interest rates again, and Australia's workers are once more being blamed for driving inflation, writes David Peetz.

title.children: Don't blame Australia's lowest-paid workers if interest rates rise again

image.altText: A birds eye view of a mine with a pit and a pool of water.

items.synopsis: This Bougainville community is living on a literal goldmine, but some residents say that despite it being abandoned for decades, it poses a risk to their environment and human rights.

title.children: The waters in this part of a remote jungle are so blue there are fears over what runs in them

image.altText: A man wearing a car backwards stands by a bright green car, with its doors open.

items.synopsis: A man accused of threatening Nick Kyrgios's mother at gunpoint and stealing her son's car, pleads not guilty to aggravated armed robbery in the ACT Magistrates Court.

title.children: Canberra man pleads not guilty to pointing gun at Nick Kyrgios's mother and stealing tennis star's Tesla

image.altText: A man sitting on a rock inside a cave.

items.synopsis: Palaeontologists say they found the oldest known burial site in the world, containing remains of a small-brained distant relative of humans previously thought incapable of complex behaviour.

title.children: World's oldest burial site found in South Africa, dating back to at least 200,000 BC

image.altText: a man wearing a suit standing in front of video and photo cameras

items.synopsis: The full findings into the Victoria Cross recipient's unsuccessful defamation lawsuit are now public, and outline Justice Anthony Besanko's reasoning. Here are five findings you may have missed.

title.children: Five key findings from the Ben Roberts-Smith judgement

image.altText: Ben Roberts-Smith receives Victoria Cross

items.synopsis: The Ben Roberts-Smith verdict has reopened the wounds of a shameful period of Australian military history that demonstrates how the leadership of the ADF has failed, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Three ADF failures built the culture that enabled Ben Roberts-Smith

image.altText: woman looks lovingly at her chihuahua puppy who fits in her hand

items.synopsis: New laws require a landlord to give a reason for refusing a tenant's request to have a pet, like if the animal is dangerous or the property is too small for it.

title.children: When Kelly was told she couldn't have a dog in her rental property, she wanted to know why

image.altText: A dark living area with couch and television and a window covered in mesh cladding.

items.synopsis: Evidence is growing about the importance of being exposed to enough natural light, but what rights do residents have to protect their access to it?

title.children: Construction turned Huw's bright apartment into a 'dungeon'. There was nothing he could do

image.altText: Scott Morrison looks to the left as he speaks in front of a dark backdrop with an Australian flag to the left.

items.synopsis: A review into a Morrison-government-era grant funding program finds only two of 171 projects attached to the program were "highly suitable" and almost half were based in marginal electorates.

title.children: Report finds Morrison government's administration of health program 'fell short of ethical requirements'

image.altText: A woman sitting on a staircase, wearing augmented reality goggles.

items.synopsis: Apple unveils a long-rumoured headset that will place its users between the virtual and real worlds.

title.children: Apple has unveiled a new AR headset. Here's what to know about Vision Pro

image.altText: Abel Tesfaye and Lily Rose Depp in The Idol, with Tesfaye holding Depp from behind.

items.synopsis: A troubled young pop star manipulated and taken advantage of by a sinister impresario. We've seen it before — and some say we've seen it done much better. Why is there so much controversy surrounding HBO's The Idol?

title.children: HBO's The Idol finally dropped and it's being described as a 'toxic man's fantasy'

image.altText: A closeup of Puck the dolphin eating a fish at the Monkey Mia feeding program

items.synopsis: The handfeeding of wild dolphins is a lucrative ecotourism industry in parts of Australia, but the impact of the practice has researchers divided. So, why are experts split on the issue, and what does the science say?

title.children: Should we be handfeeding wild dolphins? Even the experts are divided

image.altText: Cate Blanchett, a middle-aged white woman in a nun's habit, and Aswan Reid, a young Aboriginal boy, run through a wheat field.

items.synopsis: In its 70th year, the festival program boasts almost 300 films — from international heavy hitters and award-winners to lesser-known gems and trailblazing debuts. Here are nine you can't miss.

title.children: Cate Blanchett as a renegade nun, Meg Ryan in an erotic thriller: Sydney Film Festival highlights

image.altText: Burke speaks sitting at a desk with a sunrise backdrop behind him.

items.synopsis: Mining, construction and farming and other business groups have mounted a campaign over changes the Employment Minister Tony Burke says the government is not proposing to make.

title.children: 'Strangest debate': Burke says business launched campaign against laws government is not proposing

image.altText: Three men in sheriff uniform outside a forest.

items.synopsis: US investigators trudge through rugged terrain to reach the site where a private plane slammed into a mountain, killing four people, after earlier flying over the nation's capital, prompting officials to scramble fighter jets.

title.children: Pilot of plane that flew over Washington DC and crashed appeared slumped over, officials say

image.altText: An Indian man sitting on hospital bed with legs in bandages.

items.synopsis: Survivors recount seeing mangled metal and hearing the cries of children in the chaotic first moments after the train crash in the state of Odisha in India.

title.children: 'I am haunted by it': Survival stories from India's devastating train crash

image.altText: Convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein in his 2017 mug shot.

items.synopsis: More than 4,000 pages of documents related to the disgraced financier's death have been obtained under the Freedom of Information Act, including a detailed psychological reconstruction of the events leading to his suicide in prison.

title.children: New details about events surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's death revealed in documents

image.altText: An aerial view of smoke from an explosive attack in a field.

items.synopsis: Russia claims to have thwarted a major Ukrainian offensive in the Donetsk region, killing hundreds of troops, while Kyiv accuses Moscow of spreading lies.

title.children: Russia claims it killed 250 Ukrainian troops while Kyiv says it is 'shifting to offensive actions'

image.altText: a kangaroo stands behind a wire fence

items.synopsis: An unexpected discovery when comparing the head shapes and teeth of red kangaroos inside and outside the Australian dog fence has been made by researchers, with one group growing up quicker.

title.children: Surprise link between dog fence and slower-growing red kangaroos emerges

image.altText: Police radar gun

items.synopsis: Anders Wiklöf says he really regrets driving 30 kilometres per hour over the limit in Finland, where such penalties are based an offender's income.

title.children: Driver slapped with $195,796 speeding fine in Finland
